title: Open Tibial Fracture
diagnosis_topic: Gustilo Grade II Open Tibial Fracture from Motorcycle Accident
setup_script: “A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle crash. He has a visibly deformed right lower leg with bone protruding through a wound on the anteromedial shin. He is otherwise healthy, with no significant past medical history. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “You see a 5 cm laceration with visible tibial shaft, moderate contamination with dirt. Pedal pulses are palpable, sensation is intact.”
“There is no active arterial bleeding, oozing only from wound edges.”
“You administer cefazolin and gentamicin within the first hour. What do you want to do next?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident covers wound with saline-soaked sterile dressing and immobilizes
dynamic_flow.reply: “You place a saline-soaked dressing and apply a temporary splint, protecting the tissue.”
“Plain radiographs show a comminuted midshaft tibial fracture with minimal displacement.”
“How would you classify this open fracture?”
“Correct—this would be classified as a Gustilo-Anderson Grade II open tibia fracture.”
“Orthopedics plans to take the patient to the OR within 6 hours for irrigation, debridement, and external fixation.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays antibiotics or operative intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: “The risk of infection and osteomyelitis increases significantly.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about compartment syndrome
dynamic_flow.reply: “Postoperatively, you are monitoring for worsening pain, tense compartments, sensory changes, and diminished pulses.”
“Plan is staged: conversion to intramedullary nailing after soft tissue condition improves.”
“Options include repeat irrigation/debridement, delayed closure, or negative pressure wound therapy.”
“Physical therapy and early range of motion are initiated when safe; weight-bearing is advanced gradually.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about long-term outcome
dynamic_flow.reply: “Risk of infection, delayed union, and functional impairment remain. Patient will require prolonged rehabilitation.”

critical_decision_points: Early administration of appropriate antibiotics and tetanus prophylaxis
Proper classification of the open fracture (Gustilo
Timely irrigation, debridement, and external stabilization
Monitoring for compartment syndrome and infection
Planning for staged conversion to definitive fixation

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths:You promptly identified the need for antibiotics and tetanus prophylaxis and correctly prioritized early orthopedic consultation for operative management. Your communication with the team was clear and structured.
Areas for Improvement:Further refinement is needed in discussing classification systems, compartment syndrome monitoring, and staged fixation planning. Be more explicit about postoperative wound management options.
